maml:description.maml:para: Updates the path environment variable with a new directory and can be used in this session.
Updates the path environment variable with a new directory and can be used in this session.

maml:Description.maml:para: The Directory you want added to the path environment variable.
The Directory you want added to the path environment variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-DirectoryToPath -Directory c:\mypath

dev:remarks.maml:para: $env:PATH will now have 'c:\mypath' added to it.

maml:description.maml:para: Starts the remote desktop process with options set.
Allows you to start a remote desktop process and set options not made avliable by mstsc like the gateway host name.

maml:Description.maml:para: A valid computer name, IPv4 address, or IPv6 address - Specifies the remote computer to which you want to connect
Screen resolution if not full screen. 1024x768 by default.
Use a gateway for the connection.
Username to use to log into the remote computer.
If specified remote desktop will be full screen.
A valid computer name, IPv4 address, or IPv6 address - Specifies the remote computer to which you want to connect
If specified remote desktop will be full screen.
Screen resolution if not full screen. 1024x768 by default.
Use a gateway for the connection.
Username to use to log into the remote computer.

maml:alert.maml:para: Version: 1.0 Author: Sytone Creation Date: 1/18/2016 Purpose/Change: Initial script development

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Connect-RemoteDesktop -FullAddress mrserver -FullScreen -UseMultimon

dev:remarks.maml:para: Connect-RemoteDesktop -FullAddress mrserver -FullScreen -UseMultimon -GatewayHostName my.gateway.com

maml:description.maml:para: Pulls a configuration value from the local configuration file.
Pulls a configuration value from the local configuration file.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Test-Path (Get-PsfConfig -Key DevelopmentFolder)

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the value for the DevelopmentFolder key.

maml:description.maml:para: This provides a fast way to get the enlistments for the PowerShell framework to make and submit modifications.
This provides a fast way to get the enlistments for the PowerShell framework to make and submit modifications.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Initialize-PsfGit

dev:remarks.maml:para: Will make a PowerShellFrame and PowerShellFramModule directories in the dev folder in your provile and will then clone the enlistments.

maml:description.maml:para: Prompt the user for a choice, and return the (0-based) index of the selected item

command:parameter.maml:name: Message

maml:Description.maml:para: This is the prompt that will be presented to the user. Basically, the question you're asking.

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: Choose one of the following options:

maml:Description.maml:para: A Hashtable where the keys represent the choices (or menu items), with optional ampersands (&) in them to mark (unique) characters which can be used to select each item, and the values represent help text to be displayed to the user when they ask for help making their decision.
An additional caption that can be displayed (usually above the Message) as part of the prompt
The (0-based) index of the menu item to select by default (defaults to zero).

Prompt the user to select more than one option. This changes the prompt display for the default PowerShell.exe host to show the options in a column and allows them to choose multiple times. Note: when you specify MultipleChoice you may also specify multiple options as the default!
Causes the Choices objects to be output instead of just the indexes

command:parameter.maml:name: Message

maml:Description.maml:para: This is the prompt that will be presented to the user. Basically, the question you're asking.

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: Choose one of the following options:

maml:Description.maml:para: An array of strings representing the choices (or menu items), with optional ampersands (&) in them to mark (unique) characters which can be used to select each item.
An additional caption that can be displayed (usually above the Message) as part of the prompt
The (0-based) index of the menu item to select by default (defaults to zero).

Prompt the user to select more than one option. This changes the prompt display for the default PowerShell.exe host to show the options in a column and allows them to choose multiple times. Note: when you specify MultipleChoice you may also specify multiple options as the default!
Causes the Choices objects to be output instead of just the indexes

A Hashtable where the keys represent the choices (or menu items), with optional ampersands (&) in them to mark (unique) characters which can be used to select each item, and the values represent help text to be displayed to the user when they ask for help making their decision.
An array of strings representing the choices (or menu items), with optional ampersands (&) in them to mark (unique) characters which can be used to select each item.
An additional caption that can be displayed (usually above the Message) as part of the prompt

command:parameter.maml:name: Message

maml:Description.maml:para: This is the prompt that will be presented to the user. Basically, the question you're asking.

command:parameter.dev:defaultValue: Choose one of the following options:

maml:Description.maml:para: The (0-based) index of the menu item to select by default (defaults to zero).

Prompt the user to select more than one option. This changes the prompt display for the default PowerShell.exe host to show the options in a column and allows them to choose multiple times. Note: when you specify MultipleChoice you may also specify multiple options as the default!
Causes the Choices objects to be output instead of just the indexes

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Read-Choice "WEBPAGE BUILDER MENU" "&Create Webpage","&View HTML code","&Publish Webpage","&Remove Webpage","E&xit"

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: [bool](Read-Choice "Do you really want to do this?" "&No","&Yes" -Default 1)

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example takes advantage of the 0-based index to convert No (0) to False, and Yes (1) to True. It also specifies YES as the default, since that's the norm in PowerShell.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: Read-Choice "Do you really want to delete them all?" @{"&No"="Do not delete all files. You will be prompted to delete each file individually."; "&Yes"="Confirm that you want to delete all of the files"}

dev:remarks.maml:para: Note that with hashtables, order is not guaranteed, so "Yes" will probably be the first item in the prompt, and thus will output as index 0. Because of thise, when a hashtable is passed in, we default to Passthru output.

maml:description.maml:para: Show an Open Folder Dialog and return the directory selected by the user.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $directoryPath = Read-FolderBrowserDialog -Message "Please select a directory" -InitialDirectory 'C:\' -NoNewFolderButton

dev:remarks.maml:para: if (![string]::IsNullOrEmpty($directoryPath)) { Write-Host "You selected the directory: $directoryPath" } else { "You did not select a directory." }

maml:description.maml:para: Show input box popup and return the value entered by the user.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $textEntered = Read-InputBoxDialog -Message "Please enter the word 'Banana'" -WindowTitle "Input Box Example" -DefaultText "Apple"

dev:remarks.maml:para: if ($textEntered -eq $null) { Write-Host "You clicked Cancel" } elseif ($textEntered -eq "Banana") { Write-Host "Thanks for typing Banana" } else { Write-Host "You entered $textEntered" }

maml:description.maml:para: Show input box popup and return the value entered by the user.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $textEntered = Read-InputBoxDialog -Message "Please enter the word 'Banana'" -WindowTitle "Input Box Example" -DefaultText "Apple"

dev:remarks.maml:para: if ($textEntered -eq $null) { Write-Host "You clicked Cancel" } elseif ($textEntered -eq "Banana") { Write-Host "Thanks for typing Banana" } else { Write-Host "You entered $textEntered" }

maml:description.maml:para: Prompts the user with a multi-line input box and returns the text they enter, or null if they cancelled the prompt.
Prompts the user with a multi-line input box and returns the text they enter, or null if they cancelled the prompt.

maml:Description.maml:para: The message to display to the user explaining what text we are asking them to enter.
The text to display on the prompt window's title.
The default text to show in the input box.
The message to display to the user explaining what text we are asking them to enter.
The text to display on the prompt window's title.
The default text to show in the input box.

maml:alert.maml:para: Name: Show-MultiLineInputDialog Author: Daniel Schroeder (originally based on the code shown at http://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ff730941.aspx) Version: 1.0

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $userText = Read-MultiLineInputDialog "Input some text please:" "Get User's Input"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Shows how to create a simple prompt to get mutli-line input from a user.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: # Setup the default multi-line address to fill the input box with.

dev:remarks.maml:para: $defaultAddress = @' John Doe 123 St. Some Town, SK, Canada A1B 2C3 '@

$address = Read-MultiLineInputDialog "Please enter your full address, including name, street, city, and postal code:" "Get User's Address" $defaultAddress if ($address -eq $null) { Write-Error "You pressed the Cancel button on the multi-line input box." }
Prompts the user for their address and stores it in a variable, pre-filling the input box with a default multi-line address. If the user pressed the Cancel button an error is written to the console.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $inputText = Read-MultiLineInputDialog -Message "If you have a really long message you can break it apart`nover two lines with the powershell newline character:" -WindowTitle "Window Title" -DefaultText "Default text for the input box."

dev:remarks.maml:para: Shows how to break the second parameter (Message) up onto two lines using the powershell newline character (`n). If you break the message up into more than two lines the extra lines will be hidden behind or show ontop of the TextBox.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $multiLineText = Read-MultiLineInputBoxDialog -Message "Please enter some text. It can be multiple lines" -WindowTitle "Multi Line Example" -DefaultText "Enter some text here..."

dev:remarks.maml:para: if ($multiLineText -eq $null) { Write-Host "You clicked Cancel" } else { Write-Host "You entered the following text: $multiLineText" }

maml:description.maml:para: Show an Open File Dialog and return the file selected by the user.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- EXAMPLE 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: $filePath = Read-OpenFileDialog -WindowTitle "Select Text File Example" -InitialDirectory 'C:\' -Filter "Text files (*.txt)|*.txt"

dev:remarks.maml:para: if (![string]::IsNullOrEmpty($filePath)) { Write-Host "You selected the file: $filePath" } else { "You did not select a file." }
